caseStudy.content:
Nonprofits I worked with often told me how difficult branding felt, especially when trying to balance being serious and trustworthy while still capturing energy and relevance. CRFT was a conceptual project I took on to explore that challenge in the context of a music venue.

My solution was to design a system built on minimal, geometric form paired with bold, duotone treatments. The core identity is clean and restrained, while event posters and digital assets push into louder, more expressive territory to give the brand both credibility and vibrancy.

processIntro: The challenge here was to design a identity that was restrained, but still delivered the energy of a live music venue.

gallery.caption:
Logo Development

This logo suite uses basic geometric forms to represent sound and structure: square for modularity and their ties to architecture, half circles rising and falling to suggest a party from sunup to sundown, and the circle to represent the records getting spun.

Brand in Use

Artist poster templates epxerimented with clean typography and bold duotone treatments to ensure brand consistency with artist images.

Visual Language

Isolated artist image with the duotone treatment showcases how the brand can stay consistent regardless of quality or previous treatments of artist images.

Application

Mobile screens showing the system in action, paring the minimal core identity with event details, and high contrast images.

reflection:
This project really showed me how basic forms can scale into a strong brand identity. What worked well was establishing clear rules for type and color early, allowing me to keep brand consistency across posters, screens, and social media posts.

If I were to continue, I'd build out a more extensive toolkit for venues to use independently
